attributes.title: Interoceptive/exteroceptive attention and visuo-spatial perspective-taking
attributes.description: The present experimental research based on https://osf.io/v8gwr study and will advance research on the relation between interoception and embodied processing in two important ways. First, the experiment will create manipulations and measures that focus on the same sensorimotor systems of the body. Second, two equally difficult attention orientation manipulations will be used, ruling out task difficulty and subsequent success motivation as alternative explanations for the observed results. In addition, this experiment will also directly assess success motivation using the DSSQ, as well as dispositional mindfulness using the MAAS.

q1.value: Experiment: Effects of interoceptive/exteroceptive attention, motivation, and dispositional mindfulness on visuo-spatial perspective-taking

q2.value: Thorsten Michael Erle, Karoline Schmid, Alexandra Ivanova, Sabina Narymbaeva

q3.value:
Previous research has shown that interoceptive capabilities, specifically interoceptive accuracy (the ability to perceive signals from the bodily interior), correlate with level-2 visuo-spatial perspective-taking as an exemplary embodied process. The rationale underlying these findings is that people who have a close connection to their body have an advantage while performing embodied simulations. People with a high interoceptive accuracy will generally more frequently perceive signals from the bodily modalities. In this study, we experimentally manipulate the attention for such signals by focusing participants' attention inwards (on their bodily sensations) or outwards (on sounds heard via headphones). It is predicted that focusing participants' attention on their body will improve performance on a visuo-spatial perspective-taking task that involves embodied simulation (i.e., result in more efficient simulations and thus faster perspective-taking). In contrast to previous studies on this subject (see this project), interoceptive attention is focused on the motor rather than the cardiac system because it is more closely tied to the embodiment of perspective-taking. 

Furthermore, in previous research it was found that focusing attention to the cardiac system was perceived as much more difficult than the exteroceptive attention manipulation. Perceived difficulty within one task (here the attention orientation task) can trigger success motivation for subsequent tasks, which will translate into better performance. The present experiment will also address this alternative explanation based on success motivation. It is predicted that higher perceived difficulty on the attention orientation task is positively related to success motivation after this task, which then predicts faster reaction times on the subsequent VPT task. 

Finally, the novel interoceptive attention manipulation adopted for this study involves elements of mindfulness meditation techniques. Therefore, dispositional mindfulness could impact how much participants are affected by the attention manipulations. Dispositional mindfulness will be assessed to investigate this.

q4.value:
1) It is predicted that there will be an interaction between the two manipulated variables of this study: Attention and Perspective. The time to complete perspective-taking trials will be shorter for participants of the interoceptive attention condition compared to the exteroceptive attention condition. For egocentric trials that do not involve embodied simulations, however, no differences in reaction times between the two attention conditions are expected. This hypothesis will be tested as a two-way interaction within a mixed model framework.

2) It is predicted that there is an indirect effect of perceived difficulty of the attention manipulation on VPT performance (reaction times), mediated via success motivation. Higher perceived difficulty of the attention manipulation will increase motivation to succeed on a subsequent task and therefore in this study result in faster reaction times on the VPT task. This hypothesis will be tested in line with recent recommendations (Yzerbyt, V., Muller, D., Batailler, C., & Judd, C. M. (2018). New recommendations for testing indirect effects in mediational models: The need to report and test component paths. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 115, 929-943.).

3) It is predicted that dispositional mindfulness has an effect on the strength of the relation between attention conditions and VPT performance (reaction times). Since multiple patterns of results are conceivable, this hypothesis is non-directional: Either, participants with higher dispositional mindfulness will be impacted by the interoceptive attention manipulation more strongly, leading to a greater reduction in perspective-taking reaction times. Alternatively, the high frequency with which these individuals attend to their bodies could also lead to habituation and therefore a smaller effect of the momentary body attention manipulation on reaction times (compared to less mindful individuals). In a similar vein it could be that highly mindful individuals are affected negatively by the exteroceptive attention manipulation because it disrupts their default focus of attention. Although the predicted mean patterns of reaction times differ between these outcomes, all possibilities would be evident in a three-way interaction between the two manipulated variables (Attention and Perspective) and participants' measured dispositional mindfulness within a mixed model framework.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This experimental study has a cross-sectional 2 (Attention: Interoceptive vs. Exteroceptive; between) x 2 (Perspective: Egocentric vs. Perspective-Taking; within) mixed design. Success motivation and dispositional mindfulness will be measured as continuous predictors. There will be 96 trials of the perspective-taking task (48 "egocentric", that is, the angular disparity between participant and target is 0° or 40° versus 48 "perspective-taking" trials, that is, angular disparities of 80°/120°/160°). Within the VPT paradigm, factors will be counterbalanced as usual (see, e.g., Erle, T.M., & Topolinski, S. (2017). The grounded nature of psychological perspective-taking. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 112, 683-695.).

q9.value:
- Participants will be randomly assigned to inwards or outwards conditions.
- The sequence of VPT trials will be randomized anew for every participant.
- The presented animate and non-animate sounds in the exteroceptive attention condition will be randomly selected.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through SONA Systems, an online-system for the recruitment for psychological studies. It is to be expected that mostly (psychology) students will participate in the study. The study will take place at the social psychology laboratory of Tilburg University and will be conducted in English. In exchange for completing the study, course credits will be offered. The entire procedure lasted approximately 30 minutes. Before starting the study all participants should give informed consent concerning the study protocol. The study will be carried out individually on a computer in soundproof cubicles; to complete some tasks, participants will need to wear provided headphones.

q13.value: The sample size will be the same as in the first experiment of this project (see registration here). The target sample size is N = 128.

q14.value: The rationale for the sample size is the same as in the first experiment of this project (see registration here).

q15.value: Because the laboratory for our study is booked for two weeks, data collection will be terminated two weeks after the study begins or when the final sample size is reached.

question.value:
Attention (between-subjects): 
Participants will be randomly assigned to complete either the interoceptive or the exteroceptive attention orientation task. During the task, all participants will be asked to wear headphones. Instructions will be displayed on the computer screen. In both conditionss, the task consist of 5 trials of the same length (10, 35, 45, 25, and 60 seconds, respectively) and every first trial is a training trial. The beginning and end of each trial will be indicated by a sound signal. 

In the exteroceptive attention condition, participants will hear randomly generated series of sounds and they will be asked to count only the sounds that are produced by a living being (e.g., animal sounds, human laughter etc.). After each trial participants will indicate the number of animate sounds and their confidence in this guess. 

In the interoceptive attention condition, participants' attention will be focused on different muscles of the body as the embodiment of perspective-taking involves a motor movement simulation which should be most strongly related to the motor system. Participants will be asked to direct their attention to different muscle groups (abdomen, right and left biceps and quadriceps) by contracting these muscles. They are further asked to focus their attention on the resulting sensations within the muscle and not to think about anything else. Participants are asked to count whenever they lose this focus of attention (i.e., when they focus their thoughts on something different than the resulting interoceptive signals). Similarly to the exteroceptive attention condition, after each trial participants will indicate how many times they lost the attention and how confident they are in these estimations. 

Perspective-taking (within-subjects): 
Participants will complete 96 randomly presented trials (48 trials per each Egocentric vs. Perspective-Taking) of a level-2 visuo-spatial perspective-taking task (within subject manipulation). During every trial, participants see a person (the “target”) sitting at a table with two objects (book and banana). Their task is to report with which hand the "target" will “grab” one of the adjusted objects, using two response keys on the keyboard. The angular disparity between participant and target is manipulated so that the target sits at an angle of 0˚, 40˚, 80˚, 120˚, or 160˚ (clockwise or counterclockwise) from the participant. Perspective-taking trials will include an angular disparity greater than 40°, and all angular disparities below this threshold will be treated as egocentric trials. The dependent variable is the reaction time (RT) on the visuo-spatial perspective-taking task (measured in ms).

The main dependent variable is the reaction time on the visuo-spatial perspective-taking task (measured in ms). Further measures that are taken during the study are: 

- Errors on the perspective-taking task 
- Level of perceived difficulty, frustration and fun (reverse-coded) concerning body-attention and external-attention task (5-point likert scales) 
- Demographic data will include gender, age, level of experience with meditation, fitness, and BMI (self-reported height and weight) 
- Questionnaires: Success Motivation Subscale (Dundee Stress State Questionnaire (DSSQ); subscale success motivation), Toronto-Alexithymia Scale; Body Consciousness Scale, Mindful Attention Awareness Scale (MAAS)

Manipulation Check: Participants' answers to the three questions (difficulty, frustration and fun with the attention task) will be averaged (fun = reverse-coded). 

Success motivation: As a general indicator of success motivation the average value of all 7 items will be used. 

Dispositional mindfulness: Dispositional mindfulness will be computed as the average of all 15 items of the MAAS.

Main analyses: 
1. The first and third hypotheses will be tested in a linear mixed model analysis. Reaction times for correct trials of the perspective-taking task will serve as the dependent measure. The model will include fixed effects of Attention (contrast coded as: -0.5 = inwards-oriented vs. +0.5 = outwards oriented), Perspective (contrast coded as: -0.5 = egocentric vs. +0.5 = perspective-taking), Dispositional Mindfulness, and their interactions. A random effect of subject for the perspective-taking factor will be included. Hypothesis 1 is tested as the two-way interaction between Attention and Perspective. Hypothesis 3 is tested as the three-way interaction between Attention, Perspective, and Dispositional Mindfulness.

 2. The second hypothesis will be tested in several regression analyses (mediation analysis). Perceived attention task difficulty will serve as the independent variable, success motivation as the mediator, and reaction time for correct trials of the VPT task as the dependent variable. This analysis will be conducted at the participant level and the individual steps of the analyses follow recent recommendations documented elsewhere (Yzerbyt, V., Muller, D., Batailler, C., & Judd, C. M. (2018). New recommendations for testing indirect effects in mediational models: The need to report and test component paths. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 115, 929-943.).

Additional analyses: 
1. It is assumed that both attention tasks are equally difficult to complete. To test this, difficulty scores of the two attention conditions will be compared using an independent samples Bayesian t-test. 

2. In addition to the model above (RT analysis for correct trials), errors (which are excluded from this main analysis) will be analyzed as a secondary dependent variable. The model specification is the same as above, but RTs for correct trials are replaced by errors (logistic regression framework).

q20.value:
- Scores on all scales and subscales (Manipulation Check, Success motivation, Dispositional mindfulness) will be computed as their average. All averages will be z-standardized to center participants' scores around the grand mean. 

- BMI will be computed according to the common formula, using participants' self-reported height and weight. For this, height which is assessed in cm will be transformed into m. 

- For exploratory analyses, RTs might be transformed to achieve a normal distribution. However, the main analysis will operate on untransformed RTs.

q21.value: All Frequentist analyses will use the standard criterion of alpha = .05. The Bayesian analyses will not use any threshold and act more descriptively, quantifying the evidence for/against the respective hypotheses.

q22.value:
Participants: 
- Participants in the external-attention condition who report on average having heard 150% of the actually presented sounds (e.g., if 8 sounds have to be detected and a participant reports more than 12 sounds) will be excluded. 
- Participants in the internal-attention conditions who report that they lost the attention more than 1 time per 3 second in each trial (e.g., more than 9 times in the 25 seconds trial, over 12/35s, over 15/45s, and over 20/60s) will be excluded from the data analysis. 

Trials: 
- For the main analysis (perspective-taking RTs), all trials where participants responded with the wrong response key will be excluded. This is because during those trials it cannot be assumed that the participants correctly engaged in perspective-taking/remained egocentric. 
- RT outliers will be screened and excluded using the common Tukey method (i.e., RTs > 75th percentile + 1.5*IQR are excluded) applied at the participant level and for every level of angular disparity separately. If the lower Tukey bound (25th percentile - 1.5*IQR) is a negative integer, it will be replaced by a threshold of 200ms, as responses faster than this are unrealistic for the perspective-taking task.

q23.value: Missing data within non mixed-model analyses will be deleted list-wise.

q24.value:
In addition to the main analysis, the following questions might be explored:

- In case perceived difficulty is significantly different between the two conditions: Does this have an impact on the performance in the visuo-spatial perspective-taking task?
- Do BMI, experience with meditation, interoceptive sensibility, alexithymia, or general fitness play a role for visuo-spatial perspective-taking?

q1.value: The effect of order of confidence judgments on the confidence-accuracy relationship

q3.value:
Primary questions
1.	Does the order of verbal and numeric confidence ratings influence the confidence-accuracy relationship?
2.	Which approach to eliciting confidence judgments has the most predictive power?

Secondary questions
1.	Which type of statement do people prefer to give?
2.	Which type of statement do people prefer to receive?
3.	How do individuals prefer to express confidence?

q4.value: We expect that a scale rating following a verbal statement will strengthen the relationship between confidence and accuracy (directional), based on 1) the fact that people prefer to give confidence verbally (Wallsten & Budescu, 1995), 2) that the accuracy of people’s memory reports is highest when they are allowed to choose how coarsely/precisely they report (Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996), and 3) the cognitive interview results in more information than a standard interview, in part because it uses multiple retrieval opportunities, which involve obtaining a first narrative followed by probing for more information about that narrative (Schreiber-Compo & Fisher, 2007). Based on preliminary data from our lab and previous work (Kenchel, Reisberg, & Dodson, 2017; Pennekamp, Batstone, & Mansour, 2019) we expect individuals to prefer receiving ratings of confidence numerically but to prefer giving ratings of confidence verbally. There are no specific hypotheses for the preference of other types of scales. We will examine this relationship in an exploratory fashion.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment will use a mixed design and involve a manipulation of target presence within-subjects (e.g. target present lineup, target absent lineup). Confidence statements will involve a manipulation of order: using a scale before giving a verbal statement (as recommended in the U.S.A.) [scale + verbal] or giving a verbal statement before a scale rating [verbal + scale]. This variable will have two levels and will be manipulated between-subjects. We will also vary target videos (2) but will collapse across them for analyses.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to view a target video. Participants will also be randomly assigned to whether they see a target-absent versus target-present lineup first. Participants will then be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions (verbal then numeric, numeric then verbal).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be adults with sufficient visual capacity to view a computer screen. Participants will be recruited from the QMU population (using the RPS, Psychology Participant Database, Word of Mouth) as well as the community (Word of Mouth, online via social media and websites such as Gumtree). If resources are available, participants will be recruited via online tools like Mechanical Turk. As this will be an online study, participants will click a button labelled “Consent” to consent to participate. Participants will then read the letter of information. This project will be part of a larger study examining best ways to obtain eyewitness evidence with regard to confidence statements. We expect to begin data collection in February 2020. 


We will exclude participants that do not provide at least one identification decision and one confidence decision.

q13.value: Jusslin, Wilson, and Olsson (1996) suggest that the ideal sample per point in a calibration analysis is 200 participants, however, no empirical analysis has addressed the issue of sample size with confidence-accuracy calibration curves and it is common to have samples of 100 participants per point. This experiment will have 4 cells (2 target presence x 2 order) and calibration curves will have 3 points each. However, target presence will be manipulated within subjects. Thus, a sample of 1200 would be ideal. However, it is unlikely that we will have the opportunity to collect this much data. We anticipate collecting 400 participants which will allow us to address our primary question--specifically, this will allow us to compare the confidence-accuracy relationship for the numeric followed by verbal condition versus the verbal followed by numeric condition.

q15.value: Data collection will terminate when we have collected data for 200 participants per bin per cell.

question.value: There will be two variables with two levels each. We will manipulate order of confidence ratings (e.g. verbal then numeric, numeric then verbal) between-subjects. We will manipulate target-presence (e.g. present or not present) within-subjects. We will manipulate the actors in the mock crime video (one of two) shown to ensure stimulus sampling (Wells & Windschitl, 1996). However, all analyses will be collapsed across the actor variable.

1.	We will measure identification accuracy (correct decision made, e.g. correct identification or correct rejection) as the dependent variable. We will measure confidence in the participant’s own words (verbatim) and numerically (on a scale of 0 to 100). 
2.	For the secondary analyses, we will measure which type of statement individuals prefer to give (verbal, numeric or other) and which type of statement individuals prefer to receive (verbal, numeric, or other). We will measure which type of scale individuals prefer to rate confidence on when given the choice.

Analyses relevant to the outlined research
1.	Does the order of verbal and numeric confidence ratings influence the confidence-accuracy relationship?
a.	t-test with confidence condition as the independent variable (two levels) and rating as the dependent variable (separate analyses for verbal and numeric judgments)
b.	The CAC curves for each of the 2 confidence conditions will be compared to assess whether there are differences in scale ratings as a function of whether the scale preceded a verbal statement or whether the scale followed a verbal statement related to confidence/the reason for the identification. 
c.	Pairwise comparisons between the conditions for each level of confidence will
d.	Logistic regression with confidence approach (first way confidence measured) and confidence condition rating as predictors of accuracy
e.	The CAC curves for (1) verbal, then scale, (2) scale, then verbal will be compared in order to assess which method provides the strongest confidence-accuracy relationship.
f.	Calibration statistics for the 2 confidence conditions will be compared using inferential confidence intervals


Secondary questions
4.	Which type of statement do people prefer to give?
a.	Report frequency of statement type preferred to give (i.e. verbal, numeric, both, other)
5.	Which type of statement do people prefer to receive?
a.	Report frequency of statement type preferred to receive/hear (i.e. verbal, numeric, both, other)
6.	Which type of scale do individuals choose to rate confidence? 
a.	Report frequency of scale type chosen (i.e. visual analogue scale, numeric scale, verbal scale, Likert-type scale, other)
7.	Do these frequencies differ as a function of their condition? 
a.	Z-test for proportions

2.	Analyses relevant to the body of literature broadly
3.	Do own verbal ratings align with own word ratings in the field study by Behrman and Richards (2005)?
a.	Frequency with which statements used will be reported
b.	Logistic regression used to see if verbal statement categories differentiate suspect and filler identifications (as per Behrman and Richards’ analyses)
4.	How do participant eyewitness’ own scale ratings align with own word ratings/checklist? 
a.	Report frequency that verbal statements matched the accompanying scale rating 
5.	Is the confidence-accuracy relationship stronger for identifications than rejections? Are highly confident rejections reliable? 
a.	The CAC and calibration curves for identifications will be compared to the CAC and calibration curves for rejections.
b.	Correlation coefficients will be calculated and compared for the two confidence conditions.

q20.value: Verbal judgements of confidence level and numerical ratings of confidence will be coded as low, medium, or high confidence according to Behrman and Richards’ (2005) and Mansour’s (2020) coding scheme. If sample sizes are large, we will look at the numeric confidence judgments on a finer point scale (e.g. 5 categories instead of 3). Lineup decisions will be coded as correct (suspect identifications from target-present lineups, rejections of target-absent lineups) or incorrect (filler identifications, suspect identifications from target-absent lineups). Numeric statements and scale ratings of less than 50% will be coded as low confidence. Numeric values of 50-79% will be coded as medium confidence and 80% and above as high (Mansour, 2020).

q21.value:
We expect that a scale rating following a verbal statement will lead to an improvement in the relationship between confidence and accuracy (directional). To make inferences, we will be using a one tailed test with a criterion of α >.05. Where a specific hypothesis has not been given, tests will be non-directional. 

We will use pairwise comparisons for inferential confidence intervals, applying Bonferroni correction, following Tryon (2001).

q22.value: There are no criteria of what constitutes outliers in our data set.

q23.value: We will exclude participants that do not provide at least one identification decision and one confidence decision.

q24.value: We will run exploratory analyses to test preferences for different scales. We expect there to be a relationship between confidence on visual scale ratings and accuracy, however, these analyses will be exploratory.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of order of confidence judgments on the confidence-accuracy relationship
registration_responses.q3:
Primary questions
1.	Does the order of verbal and numeric confidence ratings influence the confidence-accuracy relationship?
2.	Which approach to eliciting confidence judgments has the most predictive power?

Secondary questions
1.	Which type of statement do people prefer to give?
2.	Which type of statement do people prefer to receive?
3.	How do individuals prefer to express confidence?
registration_responses.q4: We expect that a scale rating following a verbal statement will strengthen the relationship between confidence and accuracy (directional), based on 1) the fact that people prefer to give confidence verbally (Wallsten & Budescu, 1995), 2) that the accuracy of people’s memory reports is highest when they are allowed to choose how coarsely/precisely they report (Koriat & Goldsmith, 1996), and 3) the cognitive interview results in more information than a standard interview, in part because it uses multiple retrieval opportunities, which involve obtaining a first narrative followed by probing for more information about that narrative (Schreiber-Compo & Fisher, 2007). Based on preliminary data from our lab and previous work (Kenchel, Reisberg, & Dodson, 2017; Pennekamp, Batstone, & Mansour, 2019) we expect individuals to prefer receiving ratings of confidence numerically but to prefer giving ratings of confidence verbally. There are no specific hypotheses for the preference of other types of scales. We will examine this relationship in an exploratory fashion.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomly assigned to view a target video. Participants will also be randomly assigned to whether they see a target-absent versus target-present lineup first. Participants will then be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions (verbal then numeric, numeric then verbal).
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Jusslin, Wilson, and Olsson (1996) suggest that the ideal sample per point in a calibration analysis is 200 participants, however, no empirical analysis has addressed the issue of sample size with confidence-accuracy calibration curves and it is common to have samples of 100 participants per point. This experiment will have 4 cells (2 target presence x 2 order) and calibration curves will have 3 points each. However, target presence will be manipulated within subjects. Thus, a sample of 1200 would be ideal. However, it is unlikely that we will have the opportunity to collect this much data. We anticipate collecting 400 participants which will allow us to address our primary question--specifically, this will allow us to compare the confidence-accuracy relationship for the numeric followed by verbal condition versus the verbal followed by numeric condition.

registration_responses.q8.question: The experiment will use a mixed design and involve a manipulation of target presence within-subjects (e.g. target present lineup, target absent lineup). attributes.title: Associations between adverse childhood experiences and eating disorders in adults: results from the Genetic Links to Anxiety and Depression (GLAD) study

q1.value: Associations between adverse childhood experiences and eating disorders in adults: results from the Genetic Links to Anxiety and Depression (GLAD) study

q2.value: Tom Price, Christopher Hübel, Janet Treasure, Gerome Breen

q3.value:
Childhood maltreatment (CM) is a global problem with serious life-long consequences (WHO, 2016). CM, which encompasses various forms of abuse and neglect occurring in childhood, is associated with pervasive impairments in physical and mental health (Kisely et al. 2018; Hughes et al. 2017; Nelson et al. 2017; Norman et al. 2012), increased suicidality (Angelakis et al. 2019) and a growing body of research has found associations between CM and eating disorders (EDs; Hazzard et al., 2019; Quilliot et al. 2019; Molendijk et al. 2017; Micali et al. 2017; Caslini et al. 2016). Individuals with EDs who report experiencing abuse and/or neglect as a child are more likely to drop-out of treatment, have lower rates of full recovery (Castellini et al., 2018) and present with higher levels of psychiatric comorbidity, compared to their counterparts who do not experience CM. 

Although there is a growing body of research suggesting that CM plays an important role in the development and clinical course of EDs, the number and quality of studies is small, compared to other disorders, and further research is required. In this study, we aim to investigate the association between several types of childhood maltreatment (CM) and anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), binge-eating disorder (BED), and any eating disorder specified in accordance to diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5) criteria. We will examine the associations between CM types (physical, emotional and sexual abuse; physical and emotional neglect) and EDs in adulthood for the whole sample and among men and women separately, after adjusting for sociodemographic covariates, other mental health problems and other forms of CM.

q4.value:
1) We hypothesize that exposure to multiple forms of CM will be associated with increased odds of developing any ED. 
2) We hypothesize that positive associations between exposure to multiple forms CM and EDs will be stronger for BN and BED compared with AN.  
3) We expect to find a strong positive association between childhood sexual and emotional abuse and all adult EDs outcomes, following adjustments for covariates. 
4) Conversely, we expect that experiencing childhood physical abuse and physical neglect will be positively associated with BN and BED but not AN following adjustments for covariates.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: TP will be blind to the data prior to registration of analysis plan. Access to data will be granted by GLAD study data administrators once the project registration is completed.

question.value: Cross-sectional

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Access to the data has been limited by the GLAD study administrators. To date, TP has only been granted access to a data dictionary that provides details of variables collected by the study, levels of measurement and coding within the GLAD study data library. TP has not had access to any descriptive sample statistics or patterns already observed in the data.

question.value:
Participants will be derived from the Genetic Links to Anxiety and Depression (GLAD) Study pre-existing data set. The GLAD study was set up to recruit over 40,000 individuals with depression and/or anxiety into the established National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Mental Health BioResource. As this study is the largest single study of individuals with a lifetime experience of clinical depression and anxiety conducted to date, it provides sufficient power for confirmatory research, discovery analyses and for recall studies. Details relating to recruitment, payment for participation and participant eligibility have been described in greater detail elsewhere by Davies et al. (2019). 


The current study will derive a sub-sample from the initial pool of the GLAD study: Individuals who  completed supplementary questionnaires related to eating disorders. We will also derive a reference group (i.e., psychiatric control group) of individuals with depression and/or anxiety that do not have an eating disorder, but have completed the childhood trauma screening questionnaire. Participants will be excluded if they  did not complete questionnaires relating to childhood maltreatment.

q13.value: This study will draw on a sample of over 4200 people who meet diagnostic and statistical manual, fifth edition (DSM-5) criteria for a feeding or eating disorder. We expect the sample to comprise of approximately  1500 AN, 1100 BN and 1500 BED cases.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated as soon as the project proposal and analysis plan have been pre-registered. Once pre-registration has been published, TP will request access to the relevant questionnaires and data from the GLAD study administrators.

question.value:
Sign-up Questionnaire: The GLAD study sign-up questionnaire was designed to assess core demographic and personal information as well as detailed psychological and behavioural phenotyping relevant to anxiety and depression. The questionnaire assesses a range of current and lifetime mental health problems (Davies et al. 2019). 

In the current study, we will draw upon several of the sign-up and optional questionnaires:
Dependent Variables: 
Eating Disorders: We will use a measure adapted from ED100K (Thornton et al. 2018), which has been amended by the GLAD study team to include additional questions relating to atypical anorexia nervosa. Additional information will be collected from the Binge-Eating Disorder Screener (BEDS-7, Herman et al. 2016). 

Independent Variables: 
Childhood Trauma: Childhood abuse will be assessed by the Childhood Trauma Survey (CTS; Glaesmer et al., 2013),  which includes 5 items on a Likert scale, each relating to the frequency of a distinct type of abuse (emotional, physical, sexual) or neglect (emotional, physical). Scores above the defined cut-off point for clinical utility on each item will be used to derive a dichotomous (yes/no) for each type of trauma as well as experience of ‘any CM’.

Covariates:
Sociodemographic: Age,  ancestry minority group (i.e., European vs. Asian/Black/Arab/other ancestry vs. mixed), Gender (i.e., Male, Female, Non-binary, Transgender), Sexuality (i.e., heterosexual vs. sexual minority), Employment (i.e., Student vs. non-student, unemployed),  Education (years in education) and Marital status.
Psychopathology: We will compute an ‘any lifetime mental disorder’ variable based on whether the respondent met DSM-5 (American Psychiatric Association, 2013) criteria or ICD-11 checklists for any of the following: Any depression (inc. major/atypical depression/perinatal), Any anxiety (inc. generalised anxiety disorder, specific phobia, social phobia, panic disorder, agoraphobia; post-traumatic stress disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder) substance use, or personality.
Maltreatment:  Whether someone has been exposed to other forms of CM in each model as a covariate: Physical Abuse (Yes/No), Sexual Abuse (Yes/No), Emotional Abuse (Yes/No), Physical Neglect (Yes/No), Emotional Neglect (Yes/No).

1) Responses to the Childhood Trauma Survey (CTS; Glaesmer et al., 2013) will be used to categorise participants’ experiences of maltreatment: ‘no CM’, physical abuse, emotional abuse, sexual abuse, physical neglect, emotional neglect or ‘multiple exposure’. We will generate dichotomous variables for each type of trauma, as well as a count variable for individuals reporting multiple exposure.
2) Eating disorders will be classified according to DSM-5 diagnostic criteria and participants will be designated, using a dichotomous variables, as either having an ED or not. Several categorical and continuous symptom level variables may be derived from the assessment scale for subsequent exploratory and sensitivity analyses (i.e., average monthly frequency binge eating).

Descriptive and univariate statistics will be computed and presented. We will also compute bivariate statistics for the study variables, stratifed by sex.

Analyses will comprise of multinomial logistic regression models, examining associations between childhood maltreatment types (physical abuse, emotional abuse, sexual abuse, physical neglect, emotional neglect and ‘exposure to multiple CM’) and eating disorder diagnoses (AN, BN, BED, OSDED), adjusted for demographic covariates. We will separate models for each form of abuse. Because sex differences in associations between childhood maltreatment and eating disorders have been observed (Afifi et al., 2017), we will assess for effect modification by sex by adding cross-product/interaction terms (childhood maltreatment type X sex) to the models. Participants in the psychiatric control group who also completed the CTS questionnaire will be used as reference. 

Odds ratios (OR) or risk ratios (RR) and their 95% confidence interval (CI) will be computed, after adjustments for sociodemographic and clinical variables correlated with at least one of the disordered eating indexes included in the logistic regression models to estimate adjusted ORs/RRs for exposure variables. For continuous variables, we will use generalised linear and (zero-inflated) negative binomial models. All analyses will be conducted in R (version 3.5.1), using appropriate packages - including plots.

q21.value: In all calculations, we will use a p-values < 0.002 (adjusted for multiple comparisons).

q22.value:
Data will be excluded in participants fail check items or do not respond to open questions with responses that suggest they are engaging with or comprehending the question. A case will be excluded more than 30% of the data points are missing.

Outliers will be included in the analyses.

q24.value: Following the completion of our primary confirmatory analyses, we will complete additional exploratory and sensitivity analyses. These will comprise symptom level analyses (i.e., binge-eating, compensatory behaviour, fasting), including investigation of whether differences exist between groups according to whether they have a current PTSD diagnosis or not. These exploratory / sensitivity analyses will be designated as such.

attributes.title: Methodological Variation of Screening Programs for Postpartum Mood and Anxiety Disorders in Caregivers of Infants Hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit: A scoping review
attributes.description: The objective of this scoping review is map the variation in approaches for implementing standardized screening for postpartum mood and anxiety disorders (PMADs) among caregivers with infants hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Title should include that this is a scoping review protocol, not just a scoping review.

attributes.title: Triage interventions involving primary healthcare providers to improve patient flow in emergency departments: a systematic review

q1.value: Triage interventions involving primary healthcare providers to improve patient flow in emergency departments: a systematic review

q2.value: Maya Jeyaraman, Rachel N. Alder, Leslie Copstein, Nameer Al-Yousif, Yahya Al-Yousif, Nicole Askin, Roger Suss, Ryan Zarychanski, Malcolm Doupe, simon berthelot, Cristina Villa-Roel, Jean Mireault, Patrick Tardif, Tamara Buchel, Rasheda Rabbani, Thomas Beaudry, Melissa Hartwell, Carolyn Shimmin, Jeanette Edwards, Frank Krupka, Gayle Halas, William Sevcik, Andrea Tricco, Alecs Chochinov, Brian Rowe, Ahmed Abou-Setta

q3.value: ED overcrowding poses significant challenges to many health care systems. Our objective was to systematically identify, critically-appraise and summarize evidence on the effectiveness of ED triage interventions involving primary healthcare providers (PHCPs) to improve patient flow.

q4.value: The main objective of our systematic review was to identify, critically-appraise and summarize evidence on effectiveness of ED triage interventions involving GPs, NPs, or nurses with increased authority (referred as PHCP’s in this review) to improve ED patient flow.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Types of study to be included
Any comparative study design

Condition or domain being studied
Emergency department (ED) overcrowding

Participants/population
Patient population (children and adults of any age) visiting the ED

Intervention(s), exposure(s)
Any intervention or strategy involving primary care professionals (family physicians/general practitioner (GP), nurse practitioner (NP), or nurse given increased authority) triaging patients in the ED

Comparator(s)/control
Any form of standard care

Main outcome(s)
The primary outcome of this review is "Time to provider initial assessment" (TPIA) measured in minutes. The provider is defined as either a general practitioner, nurse practitioner or a nurse with expanded role/increased responsibility.

Timing and effect measures
The mean (minutes) and standard deviation will be extracted and analyzed using appropriate data analysis software to calculate the mean differences and standard error. In the presence of heterogeneity we will not pool the data to conduct meta-analysis but we will provide a narrative summary of the results.

Additional outcome(s)
1. ED length of stay (ED LOS)
2. Proportion of patients that left without being seen (LWBS)
3. Time to triage (TT)
4. Proportion of patients leaving against medical advice (LAMA)
5. Patient satisfaction
6. Number of ED visits.

Timing and effect measures
The proportion of patient that left without being seen and LAMA - measured and reported as percentage
ED LOS, time to triage - measured and reported in minutes

Study Selection:
We will use Microsoft Excel screening forms for study selection. After a pilot-test, two reviewers will independently screen the titles and abstracts of citations identified by our search strategy. Each of the screened abstracts will be marked as included, excluded or unsure. We will then retrieve full-texts for the screened abstracts marked as either included or unsure. After full-text screening all the studies that fit the review eligibility criteria will be included in the systematic review. Any disagreements between reviewers during screening will be resolved through consensus or by third-party adjudication.

We will use Microsoft Excel spreadsheets for data extraction and for data management. It will be pilot tested on a sample of studies prior to the data extraction phase. Two review authors will independently extract study demographics and the outcome data from the included studies and any conflicts will be resolved through consensus or third party adjudication.

The following study data will be extracted:
1. Study design
2. Type of ED: Urban versus Rural
3. Type of patients seen in the ED: Adult ED versus Pediatric ED versus Mixed ED
4. Type of primary healthcare professional involved: Nurse practitioner (NP) versus General practitioner (GP) versus Nurse given increased authority
5. Duration of intervention
6. Country
7. Acuity levels of patients visiting ED

The outcome data will be extracted as follows:
1. TPIA, ED LOS and TT: Mean (minutes) and SD
2. LWBS and LAMA: Percentage
3. ED visits: percentage or number of visits in both groups
4. Patient satisfaction: percentage of patients satisfied or level of satisfaction

An experienced biostatistician will be involved in the data analysis. If there are at least 2 studies reporting data for the outcomes and the data is homogenous enough to pool outcome data for meta-analysis, we will meta-analyze the data using appropriate data analysis software (Review Manager (RevMan version 5.3.1, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, Denmark) or Comprehensive Meta-Analysis Software (CMA version 3, Biostat, Englewood, NJ, USA)). Data will be pooled and analyzed separately for RCTs and non-randomized studies. A random-effects model will be used to pool the data from included studies to obtain summary effect estimate. We will present the results either as Mean difference with 95% confidence intervals for continuous outcomes or relative risks (95% confidence intervals) for dichotomous outcomes. Statistical heterogeneity of the data will be explored and quantified, using the I² statistic. If there are 10 or more studies for any single outcome, we will assess publication bias for the primary outcome by using funnel plot and Egger’s test as appropriate given the known limitations of these method. In the presence of heterogeneity we will not pool the data to conduct meta-analysis but instead we will provide a descriptive synthesis of the results for each of the review outcome. We will calculate the mean difference and SE and present data visually using forest plot without pooling it or calculating summary effect estimates.

q23.value: We will contact study authors for missing data. If unable to make contact, we will use imputation methods to deal with missing data.

q24.value:
Analysis of subgroups or subsets
We propose the following a priori subgroup and sensitivity analyses that will depend on the number of studies included, their homogeneity, and the availability of appropriate outcome: (1) Type of primary care professional (GPs vs NPs); (2) Type of study design (RCT vs. non-randomized studies); (3) Type of ED (Adult ED vs. pediatric ED); (4) Geographic area (Urban ED vs rural ED); (5) Study quality (++, +, -, NR, NA).

attributes.title: Tactile and noxious acuity using transcutaneous electrical stimuli
attributes.description: The project introduces a novel paradigm to study tactile and noxious acuity in healthy subjects.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Tactile and noxious acuity using transcutaneous electrical stimuli

Wacław M. Adamczyk1,3, Tibor Szikszay1,2, Tiffany Kung, Gabriela Carvalho & Kerstin Luedtke1,2,3

1Department of Health Sciences, Academic Physiotherapy, Pain and Exercise Research Luebeck (P.E.R.L), University of Luebeck, Luebeck, Germany.
2Department of Systems Neuroscience, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany.
3Laboratory of Pain Research, Institute of Physiotherapy and Health Sciences, The Jerzy Kukuczka Academy of Physical Education, Katowice, Poland.

other.value:
We will explore the relationship between TPD thresholds and descriptive statistics by applying Pearson r correlation coefficients.

b) Two questionnaires will be administered to participants to better characterize the population: Pain Vigilance Awareness Questionnaire (PVAQ), Fremantle Back Awareness Questionnaire (FreBAQ).

c) Manipulation check questions related to the SSp will be administered at the end of the study

d) At the end of each experimental condition participants will be asked control questions, i.e. whether they thought stimuli were applied synchronously (when two were perceived), and if how much synchronous they were.

e) Data collection is ongoing but the registration is still valid as the data collection has not been finished and data analysis was not performed.

sample.value: To detect a moderate correlation (Pearson coefficient r) between two different test procedures which measure the same construct, at least 37 subjects are required. The sample size calculation has been performed based on previous results reporting a correlation between TPD and a grating-orientation task (r = from 0.35 to 0.48) and between TPD and a two-point estimation task (r = -0.36), assuming 80% power and an alpha level of 0.05.

analyses.value:
Two-point discrimination will be extracted from psychometric functions determined for each participant, individually. The psychometric function will be created using the proportion of trials in which the sensation of two points was reported on the y-axis and the physical parameter ‘separation distance’ on the x-axis. Sigmoid functions will be fitted to the data. The 50% point from the curves indicating the threshold at which participants report two points at the probability of 0.5 will be used for statistical analysis. 

1. Pearson r correlation coefficient will be applied to test concurrent validity: TPD thresholds determined by reference standard (mechanical assessment) will be correlated with TPD threshold estimated by using mechanical assessment.

2. Thresholds will be compared using the General Linear Model (GLM) analysis with modality (electrical, mechanical) and intensity (tactile, noxious) as within-subject factors. Mean TPD thresholds will be compared using planned paired Student t-tests.

3. Pain ratings will be entered into the General Linear Model (GLM) analysis with modality (electrical, mechanical) and distance (eight possibilities) as within-subject factors. Spatial summation of pain will be assessed by comparing pain ratings from a single stimulus application to pain from different stimuli pairs.

Analyses will be conducted using MATLAB R2017b (MathWorks Inc, Natick, Massachusetts) and the STATISTICA data analysis software, version 13 (StatSoft Inc., Tulsa, OK, USA). The level of significance will be set at p < 0.05.

outliers.value: Data will be excluded from analysis in case of lack of stimuli discriminations during the examination. Such a case does not allow to plot psychometric function and make it impossible to extract the two-point discrimination threshold.

dependent.value:
In this study, we will use callipers for the mechanical determination of the TPD thresholds because it is the most common technique to assess lumbar tactile acuity in healthy controls as well as in patients with chronic low back pain. Participants will be exposed to 8 series of measurements for each stimulus intensity (tactile, noxious). Each series will consist of eight different trials, seven of them will be based on stimuli pairs, each with different separations between stimulated points (2.00, 4.0, 6.0, 8.0, 10.0, 12.0, 14.0cm) and the one trial will be a control stimulus applied to one single location (a “catch” trial). The sequence of stimuli in each of the series will be generated randomly using the MATLAB R2017b (MathWorks Inc, Natick, Massachusetts). The same procedure will be repeated with electrocutaneous stimuli. Electrodes will be placed with the same separation distances as these used for mechanical paradigm. 

In general, TPD will be determined based on the typical psychophysical method of the two-alternative forced-choice task (2AFC). After each stimuli pair or single stimulus, participants have to decide if they felt the touch in two locations (“two”), or if they felt it in only one location (“one”). After the discrimination task, subjects will be asked to rate the intensity of pain they have experienced on 0-10 Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) ranging from “0” (no pain at all) to “10” (the worst pain imaginable).

conditions.value:
One cohort of healthy participants will be examined in terms of tactile and noxious acuity using mechanical and electrocutaneous stimuli. Each condition will include exposure to 8 series of 8 stimuli, so 64 stimuli per condition will be used:

a) Mechanical tactile (stimuli applied using von Frey hairs [2g] attached to mechanical calliper)
b) Mechanical noxious (stimuli applied using PinPrick needles [512mN] attached to mechanical calliper)
c) Electrocutaneous tactile (stimuli applied using Digitimer DS8R stimulator - stimuli below pain threshold)
d) Electrocutaneous noxious (stimuli applied using Digitimer DS8R stimulator - stimuli above pain threshold)

In total, participants will receive 256 stimuli (4 testing paradigms x 8 series x stimuli).

hypothesis.value:
Q1: What is the concurrent validity of the novel paradigm for tactile acuity assessment?
H1: It is hypothesised that two-point discrimination threshold (TPD) determined by a novel paradigm is significantly correlated to the TPD threshold determined by the referenced standard (mechanical paradigm). We anticipate to observe a moderate correlation (r = 0.3 - 0.7).
Q2: Do humans discriminate tactile electrocutaneous stimuli more accurately than noxious stimuli?
H2: It is hypothesised that noxious stimuli are processed with a lower precision by the central nervous system, therefore we anticipate the mean TPD threshold to be larger for noxious stimuli compared to tactile stimuli.
Q3: Do noxious stimuli evoke spatial summation of pain?
H3: It is hypothesised that spatial summation of pain occurs for both electrocutaneous and mechanical stimuli.
